# FIFA World Cup

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the men's association football tournament. For the
women's tournament, see [FIFA Women's World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "FIFA Women's World Cup").

The **FIFA World Cup** , often simply called the **World Cup** , is an
international [association football](/wiki/Association_football "Association
football") competition contested by the senior [men's national
teams](/wiki/List_of_men%27s_national_association_football_teams "List of
men's national association football teams") of the members of the __Fédération
Internationale de Football Association__ ([FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA")), the
sport's global governing body. The championship has been awarded every four
years since the [inaugural tournament in 1930](/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup "1930
FIFA World Cup"), except in 1942 and 1946 when it was not held because of the
[Second World War](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). The current champion is
[France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national football team"),
which won its second title at the [2018 tournament](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup
"2018 FIFA World Cup") in Russia.

The current format of the competition involves a [qualification
phase](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "FIFA World Cup qualification"),
which currently takes place over the preceding three years, to determine which
teams qualify for the tournament phase, which is often called the _World Cup
Finals_. After this, 32 teams, including the automatically qualifying host
nation(s), compete in the tournament phase for the title at venues within the
host nation(s) over a period of about a month.

The 21 World Cup tournaments have been won by eight national teams.
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team")
have won five times, and they are the only team to have played in every
tournament. The other World Cup winners are
[Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football
team") and [Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football
team"), with four titles each;
[Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national
football team"), [France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national
football team") and inaugural winner
[Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football
team"), with two titles each; and
[England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national football
team") and [Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national football
team") with one title each.

The World Cup is the most prestigious association football tournament in the
world, as well as the most widely viewed and followed sporting event in the
world, exceeding even the [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic
Games"); the cumulative viewership of all matches of the [2006 World
Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") was estimated to be
26.29 billion with an estimated 715.1 million people watching the [final
match](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "2006 FIFA World Cup Final"), a ninth
of the entire population of the planet.[1][2][3][4]

17 countries have hosted the World Cup. Brazil, France, Italy, Germany and
Mexico have each hosted twice, while Uruguay, Switzerland, Sweden, Chile,
England, Argentina, Spain, the United States, Japan and South Korea (jointly),
South Africa and Russia have each hosted once. Qatar are planned as hosts of
the 2022 finals, and 2026 will be a joint hosted finals between Canada, the
United States and Mexico, which will give Mexico the distinction of being the
first country to have hosted games in three different finals.

## History

Main article: [History of the FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/History_of_the_FIFA_World_Cup "History of the FIFA World Cup")

### Previous international competitions

The world's first international football match was a challenge match played in
[Glasgow](/wiki/Glasgow "Glasgow") in 1872 between
[Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team "Scotland national football
team") and [England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national
football team"),[5] which ended in a 0–0 draw. The first international
tournament, the inaugural [British Home
Championship](/wiki/British_Home_Championship "British Home Championship"),
took place in 1884.[6] As football grew in popularity in other parts of the
world at the start of the 20th century, it was held as a [demonstration
sport](/wiki/Demonstration_sport "Demonstration sport") with no medals awarded
at the [1900](/wiki/Football_at_the_1900_Summer_Olympics "Football at the 1900
Summer Olympics") and [1904 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Football_at_the_1904_Summer_Olympics "Football at the 1904
Summer Olympics") (however, the IOC has retroactively upgraded their status to
official events), and at the [1906 Intercalated
Games](/wiki/Football_at_the_1906_Summer_Olympics "Football at the 1906 Summer
Olympics").[7]

After [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA") was founded in 1904, it tried to arrange an
international football tournament between nations outside the Olympic
framework in Switzerland in 1906. These were very early days for international
football, and the official history of FIFA describes the competition as having
been a failure.[8]

At the [1908 Summer Olympics](/wiki/Football_at_the_1908_Summer_Olympics
"Football at the 1908 Summer Olympics") in [London](/wiki/London "London"),
football became an official competition. Planned by [The Football
Association](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The Football Association") (FA),
England's football governing body, the event was for
[amateur](/wiki/Amateurism "Amateurism") players only and was regarded
suspiciously as a show rather than a competition. Great Britain (represented
by the [England national amateur football
team](/wiki/England_national_amateur_football_team "England national amateur
football team")) won the [gold medals](/wiki/Gold_medal "Gold medal"). They
repeated the feat at the [1912 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Football_at_the_1912_Summer_Olympics "Football at the 1912
Summer Olympics") in [Stockholm](/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm").

With the Olympic event continuing to be contested only between amateur teams,
[Sir Thomas Lipton](/wiki/Thomas_Lipton "Thomas Lipton") organised the [Sir
Thomas Lipton Trophy](/wiki/Sir_Thomas_Lipton_Trophy "Sir Thomas Lipton
Trophy") tournament in [Turin](/wiki/Turin "Turin") in 1909. The Lipton
tournament was a championship between individual clubs (not national teams)
from different nations, each one of which represented an entire nation. The
competition is sometimes described as _The First World Cup_ ,[9] and featured
the most prestigious professional club sides from Italy, Germany and
Switzerland, but the FA of England refused to be associated with the
competition and declined the offer to send a professional team. Lipton invited
[West Auckland](/wiki/West_Auckland_Town_F.C. "West Auckland Town F.C."), an
amateur side from [County Durham](/wiki/County_Durham "County Durham"), to
represent England instead. West Auckland won the tournament and returned in
1911 to successfully defend their title.

In 1914, FIFA agreed to recognise the [Olympic
tournament](/wiki/Football_at_the_Summer_Olympics "Football at the Summer
Olympics") as a "world football championship for amateurs", and took
responsibility for managing the event.[10] This paved the way for the world's
first intercontinental football competition, at the [1920 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Football_at_the_1920_Summer_Olympics "Football at the 1920
Summer Olympics"), contested by [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt_national_football_team
"Egypt national football team") and 13 European teams, and won by
[Belgium](/wiki/Belgium_national_football_team "Belgium national football
team").[11] [Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national
football team") won the next two Olympic football tournaments in
[1924](/wiki/Football_at_the_1924_Summer_Olympics "Football at the 1924 Summer
Olympics") and [1928](/wiki/Football_at_the_1928_Summer_Olympics "Football at
the 1928 Summer Olympics"). Those were also the first two open world
championships, as 1924 was the start of FIFA's professional era.

### World Cups before World War II

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Jules_Rimet_1933.jpg/170px-
Jules_Rimet_1933.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jules_Rimet_1933.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jules_Rimet_1933.jpg "Enlarge")

FIFA president [Jules Rimet](/wiki/Jules_Rimet "Jules Rimet") convinced the
[confederations](/wiki/FIFA#Six_confederations_and_211_national_associations
"FIFA") to promote an international football tournament.

Due to the success of the Olympic football tournaments, FIFA, with
[President](/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_FIFA "List of Presidents of FIFA")
[Jules Rimet](/wiki/Jules_Rimet "Jules Rimet") as the driving force, again
started looking at staging its own international tournament outside of the
Olympics. On 28 May 1928, the FIFA Congress in [Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam
"Amsterdam") decided to stage a world championship itself.[12] With Uruguay
now two-time official football world champions and to celebrate their
[centenary](/wiki/Centenary "Centenary") of
[independence](/wiki/Treaty_of_Montevideo_\(1828\) "Treaty of Montevideo
\(1828\)") in 1930, FIFA named [Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay "Uruguay") as the host
country of the [inaugural World Cup tournament](/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup
"1930 FIFA World Cup").

The national associations of selected nations were invited to send a team, but
the choice of Uruguay as a venue for the competition meant a long and costly
trip across the Atlantic Ocean for European sides. Indeed, no European country
pledged to send a team until two months before the start of the competition.
Rimet eventually persuaded teams from
[Belgium](/wiki/Belgium_national_football_team "Belgium national football
team"), [France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national football
team"), [Romania](/wiki/Romania_national_football_team "Romania national
football team"), and [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia_national_football_team
"Yugoslavia national football team") to make the trip. In total, 13 nations
took part: seven from South America, four from Europe and two from North
America.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Estadio_Centenario_%28vista_a%C3%A9rea%29.jpg/220px-
Estadio_Centenario_%28vista_a%C3%A9rea%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Estadio_Centenario_\(vista_a%C3%A9rea\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Estadio_Centenario_\(vista_a%C3%A9rea\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Estadio Centenario](/wiki/Centenario_Stadium "Centenario Stadium"), the
location of the first World Cup final in 1930 in [Montevideo](/wiki/Montevideo
"Montevideo"), [Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay "Uruguay")

The first two World Cup matches took place simultaneously on 13 July 1930, and
were won by [France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national
football team") and the [USA](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team
"United States men's national soccer team"), who defeated
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team "Mexico national football team")
4–1 and [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium_national_football_team "Belgium national
football team") 3–0 respectively. The first goal in World Cup history was
scored by [Lucien Laurent](/wiki/Lucien_Laurent "Lucien Laurent") of
France.[13] In the [final](/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "1930 FIFA World
Cup Final"), [Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national
football team") defeated [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team
"Argentina national football team") 4–2 in front of 93,000 people in
[Montevideo](/wiki/Montevideo "Montevideo"), and became the first nation to
win the World Cup.[14] After the creation of the World Cup, FIFA and the
[IOC](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic Committee")
disagreed over the status of amateur players, and so football was dropped from
the [1932 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1932_Summer_Olympics "1932 Summer
Olympics").[15] Olympic football returned at the [1936 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Football_at_the_1936_Summer_Olympics "Football at the 1936
Summer Olympics"), but was now overshadowed by the more prestigious World Cup.

The issues facing the early World Cup tournaments were the difficulties of
intercontinental travel, and war. Few South American teams were willing to
travel to Europe for the [1934 World Cup](/wiki/1934_FIFA_World_Cup "1934 FIFA
World Cup") and all North and South American nations except
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team")
and [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba_national_football_team "Cuba national football team")
boycotted the [1938](/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup "1938 FIFA World Cup")
tournament. Brazil was the only South American team to compete in both. The
1942 and 1946 competitions, which [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany") and
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil") sought to host,[16] were cancelled due to
[World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and its aftermath.

### World Cups after World War II

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Jogo_no_Est%C3%A1dio_do_Maracan%C3%A3%2C_antes_da_Copa_do_Mundo_de_1950.tif/lossy-
page1-220px-
Jogo_no_Est%C3%A1dio_do_Maracan%C3%A3%2C_antes_da_Copa_do_Mundo_de_1950.tif.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jogo_no_Est%C3%A1dio_do_Maracan%C3%A3,_antes_da_Copa_do_Mundo_de_1950.tif)

[](/wiki/File:Jogo_no_Est%C3%A1dio_do_Maracan%C3%A3,_antes_da_Copa_do_Mundo_de_1950.tif
"Enlarge")

The opening game of the [Maracanã Stadium](/wiki/Maracan%C3%A3_Stadium
"Maracanã Stadium") in [Rio de Janeiro](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de
Janeiro"), shortly before the [1950 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup
"1950 FIFA World Cup"). From the [National Archives of
Brazil](/wiki/Brazilian_National_Archives "Brazilian National Archives")

The [1950 World Cup](/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup "1950 FIFA World Cup"), held in
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil"), was the first to include British
participants. [British teams](/wiki/Home_Nations "Home Nations") withdrew from
FIFA in 1920, partly out of unwillingness to play against the countries they
had been at war with, and partly as a protest against foreign influence on
football,[17] but rejoined in 1946 following FIFA's invitation.[18] The
tournament also saw the return of 1930 champions
[Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football
team"), who had boycotted the previous two World Cups. Uruguay won the
tournament again after defeating the host nation Brazil, in the match called
"[Maracanazo](/wiki/Uruguay_v_Brazil_\(1950_FIFA_World_Cup\) "Uruguay v Brazil
\(1950 FIFA World Cup\)")" (Portuguese: _Maracanaço_).

In the tournaments between 1934 and [1978](/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup "1978
FIFA World Cup"), 16 teams competed in each tournament, except in 1938, when
[Austria](/wiki/Austria_national_football_team "Austria national football
team") was [absorbed](/wiki/Anschluss "Anschluss") into
[Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") after qualifying, leaving the
tournament with 15 teams, and in 1950, when
[India](/wiki/India_national_football_team "India national football team"),
[Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team "Scotland national football
team"), and [Turkey](/wiki/Turkey_national_football_team "Turkey national
football team") withdrew, leaving the tournament with 13 teams.[19] Most of
the participating nations were from Europe and South America, with a small
minority from North America, Africa, Asia, and Oceania. These teams were
usually defeated easily by the European and South American teams. Until 1982,
the only teams from outside Europe and South America to advance out of the
first round were: [USA](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team
"United States men's national soccer team"), semi-finalists in 1930;
[Cuba](/wiki/Cuba_national_football_team "Cuba national football team"),
quarter-finalists in 1938; [North
Korea](/wiki/North_Korea_national_football_team "North Korea national football
team"), quarter-finalists in [1966](/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup "1966 FIFA World
Cup"); and [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team "Mexico national
football team"), quarter-finalists in [1970](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup "1970
FIFA World Cup").

### Expansion to 32 teams

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Uruguay_Ghana.jpg/220px-
FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Uruguay_Ghana.jpg)](/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Uruguay_Ghana.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Uruguay_Ghana.jpg "Enlarge")

Interior view of the [Soccer City](/wiki/Soccer_City "Soccer City") in
[Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg"), South Africa, during a
match at the [2010 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World
Cup")

The tournament was expanded to 24 teams in [1982](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup
"1982 FIFA World Cup"),[20] and then to 32 in [1998](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup
"1998 FIFA World Cup"),[21] also allowing more teams from Africa, Asia and
North America to take part. Since then, teams from these regions have enjoyed
more success, with several having reached the quarter-finals:
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team "Mexico national football team"),
quarter-finalists in [1986](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA World Cup");
[Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroon_national_football_team "Cameroon national football
team"), quarter-finalists in [1990](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup "1990 FIFA World
Cup"); [South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea_national_football_team "South Korea
national football team"), finishing in fourth place in
[2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup");
[Senegal](/wiki/Senegal_national_football_team "Senegal national football
team"), along with [USA](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team
"United States men's national soccer team"), both quarter-finalists in 2002;
[Ghana](/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team "Ghana national football team"),
quarter-finalists in 2010; and [Costa
Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica_national_football_team "Costa Rica national football
team"), quarter-finalists in 2014. Nevertheless, European and South American
teams continue to dominate, e.g., the quarter-finalists in 1994, 1998, 2006
and 2018 were all from Europe or South America and so were the finalists of
all tournaments so far.

Two hundred teams entered the [2002 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup
"2002 FIFA World Cup") qualification rounds; 198 nations attempted to qualify
for the [2006 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World
Cup"), while a record 204 countries entered qualification for the [2010 FIFA
World Cup](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World Cup").[22]

### Expansion to 48 teams

In October 2013, Sepp Blatter spoke of guaranteeing the [Caribbean Football
Union](/wiki/Caribbean_Football_Union "Caribbean Football Union")'s region a
position in the World Cup.[23] In the edition of 25 October 2013 of the _FIFA
Weekly_ Blatter wrote that: "From a purely sporting perspective, I would like
to see globalisation finally taken seriously, and the African and Asian
national associations accorded the status they deserve at the FIFA World Cup.
It cannot be that the European and South American confederations lay claim to
the majority of the berths at the World Cup."[24] Those two remarks suggested
to commentators that Blatter could be putting himself forward for re-election
to the FIFA Presidency.[25]

Following the magazine's publication, Blatter's would-be opponent for the FIFA
Presidency, [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") President [Michel
Platini](/wiki/Michel_Platini "Michel Platini"), responded that he intended to
extend the World Cup to 40 national associations, increasing the number of
participants by eight. Platini said that he would allocate an additional berth
to [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA"), two to the [Asian Football
Confederation](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation "Asian Football
Confederation") and the [Confederation of African
Football](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African
Football"), two shared between [CONCACAF](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF") and
[CONMEBOL](/wiki/CONMEBOL "CONMEBOL"), and a guaranteed place for the [Oceania
Football Confederation](/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation "Oceania Football
Confederation").[26] Platini was clear about why he wanted to expand the World
Cup. He said: "[The World Cup is] not based on the quality of the teams
because you don't have the best 32 at the World Cup ... but it's a good
compromise. ... It's a political matter so why not have more Africans? The
competition is to bring all the people of all the world. If you don't give the
possibility to participate, they don't improve."[26]

In October 2016 FIFA president [Gianni Infantino](/wiki/Gianni_Infantino
"Gianni Infantino") stated his support for a 48-team World Cup in 2026.[27] On
10 January 2017, FIFA confirmed the 2026 World Cup will have 48 finalist
teams.[28]

### 2015 FIFA corruption case

Main article: [2015 FIFA corruption case](/wiki/2015_FIFA_corruption_case
"2015 FIFA corruption case")

By May 2015, the games were under a particularly dark cloud because of the
2015 FIFA corruption case, allegations and criminal charges of bribery, fraud
and money laundering to corrupt the issuing of media and marketing rights
(rigged bids) for FIFA games,[29] with FIFA officials accused of taking bribes
totaling more than $150 million over 24 years. In late May, the U.S. Justice
Department announced a 47-count indictment with charges of racketeering, wire
fraud and money laundering conspiracy against 14 people. Arrests of over a
dozen FIFA officials were made since that time, particularly on 29 May and 3
December.[30] By the end of May 2015, a total of nine FIFA officials and five
executives of sports and broadcasting markets had already been charged on
corruption. At the time, FIFA president Sepp Blatter announced he would
relinquish his position in February 2016.[31]

On 4 June 2015 [Chuck Blazer](/wiki/Chuck_Blazer "Chuck Blazer") while co-
operating with the [FBI](/wiki/FBI "FBI") and the Swiss authorities admitted
that he and the other members of FIFA's then-executive committee were bribed
in order to promote the 1998 and 2010 World Cups.[32] On 10 June 2015 Swiss
authorities seized computer data from the offices of [Sepp
Blatter](/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp Blatter").[33] The same day, FIFA postponed
the bidding process for the [2026 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2026_FIFA_World_Cup
"2026 FIFA World Cup") in light of the [allegations surrounding
bribery](/wiki/Garcia_Report "Garcia Report") in the awarding of the 2018 and
2022 tournaments. Then-secretary general [Jérôme
Valcke](/wiki/J%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_Valcke "Jérôme Valcke") stated, "Due to the
situation, I think it's nonsense to start any bidding process for the time
being."[34] On 28 October 2015, Blatter and FIFA VP Michel Platini, a
potential candidate for presidency, were suspended for 90 days; both
maintained their innocence in statements made to the news media.[35]

On 3 December 2015 two FIFA vice-presidents were arrested on suspicion of
bribery in the same Zurich hotel where seven FIFA officials had been arrested
in May.[36] An additional 16 indictments by the U.S. Department of Justice
were announced on the same day.[37]

### Other FIFA tournaments

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Round_of_16_Canada_vs_Switzerland_%2818852958960%29.jpg/220px-
Round_of_16_Canada_vs_Switzerland_%2818852958960%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Round_of_16_Canada_vs_Switzerland_\(18852958960\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Round_of_16_Canada_vs_Switzerland_\(18852958960\).jpg "Enlarge")

The [BC Place](/wiki/BC_Place "BC Place") in [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver
"Vancouver") hosting a [2015 Women's World
Cup](/wiki/2015_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "2015 FIFA Women's World Cup") match

An equivalent tournament for [women's
football](/wiki/Women%27s_association_football "Women's association
football"), the [FIFA Women's World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "FIFA
Women's World Cup"), was first held in
[1991](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup_1991 "FIFA Women's World Cup 1991") in
[China](/wiki/China "China").[38] The women's tournament is smaller in scale
and profile than the men's, but is growing; the number of entrants for the
2007 tournament was 120, more than double that of 1991.[39]

Men's football has been included in every [Summer Olympic
Games](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic Games") except 1896 and
1932. Unlike many other sports, the men's [football tournament at the
Olympics](/wiki/Football_at_the_Summer_Olympics "Football at the Summer
Olympics") is not a top-level tournament, and since 1992, an under-23
tournament with each team allowed three over-age players.[40] Women's football
made its [Olympic debut in
1996](/wiki/Football_at_the_1996_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_tournament
"Football at the 1996 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament").

The [FIFA Confederations Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Confederations_Cup "FIFA
Confederations Cup") is a tournament held one year before the World Cup at the
World Cup host nation(s) as a dress rehearsal for the upcoming World Cup. It
is contested by the winners of each of the six FIFA confederation
championships, along with the FIFA World Cup champion and the host
country.[41]

FIFA also organises international tournaments for youth football ([FIFA U-20
World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_U-20_World_Cup "FIFA U-20 World Cup"), [FIFA U-17 World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_U-17_World_Cup "FIFA U-17 World Cup"), [FIFA U-20 Women's
World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_U-20_Women%27s_World_Cup "FIFA U-20 Women's World Cup"),
[FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_U-17_Women%27s_World_Cup "FIFA U-17
Women's World Cup")), club football ([FIFA Club World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Club_World_Cup "FIFA Club World Cup")), and football variants
such as [futsal](/wiki/Futsal "Futsal") ([FIFA Futsal World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Futsal_World_Cup "FIFA Futsal World Cup")) and [beach
soccer](/wiki/Beach_soccer "Beach soccer") ([FIFA Beach Soccer World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Beach_Soccer_World_Cup "FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup")). The
latter three do not have a women's version, although a [FIFA Women's Club
World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_Club_World_Cup "FIFA Women's Club World Cup")
has been proposed.[42]

The [FIFA U-20 Women's World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_U-20_Women%27s_World_Cup "FIFA
U-20 Women's World Cup") is held the year before each Women's World Cup and
both tournaments are awarded in a single bidding process. The U-20 tournament
serves as a dress rehearsal for the larger competition.[43]

## Trophy

Main article: [FIFA World Cup Trophy](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy "FIFA World
Cup Trophy")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain%2C_Bobby_Moore._%287936243534%29.jpg/170px-
The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain%2C_Bobby_Moore._%287936243534%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain,_Bobby_Moore._\(7936243534\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Queen_presents_the_1966_World_Cup_to_England_Captain,_Bobby_Moore._\(7936243534\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Queen [Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II") presenting the Jules
Rimet trophy to 1966 World Cup winning England captain [Bobby
Moore](/wiki/Bobby_Moore "Bobby Moore")

From 1930 to 1970, the _[Jules Rimet Trophy](/wiki/Jules_Rimet_Trophy "Jules
Rimet Trophy")_ was awarded to the World Cup winning team. It was originally
simply known as the _World Cup_ or _Coupe du Monde_ , but in 1946 it was
renamed after the FIFA president [Jules Rimet](/wiki/Jules_Rimet "Jules
Rimet") who set up the first tournament. In [1970](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup
"1970 FIFA World Cup"), [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil
national football team")'s third victory in the tournament entitled them to
keep the trophy permanently. However, the trophy was stolen in 1983 and has
never been recovered, apparently melted down by the thieves.[44]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/FIFA_-
_replica_world_cup_trophy.JPG/170px-FIFA_-
_replica_world_cup_trophy.JPG)](/wiki/File:FIFA_-
_replica_world_cup_trophy.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:FIFA_-_replica_world_cup_trophy.JPG "Enlarge")

The current World Cup trophy, presented since 1974

After 1970, a new trophy, known as the [FIFA World Cup
Trophy](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy#FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy "FIFA World Cup
Trophy"), was designed. The experts of FIFA, coming from seven countries,
evaluated the 53 presented models, finally opting for the work of the Italian
designer [Silvio Gazzaniga](/wiki/Silvio_Gazzaniga "Silvio Gazzaniga"). The
new trophy is 36 cm (14.2 in) high, made of solid 18
[carat](/wiki/Carat_\(purity\) "Carat \(purity\)") (75%) gold and weighs 6.175
kg (13.6 lb).[45] The base contains two layers of semi-precious
[malachite](/wiki/Malachite "Malachite") while the bottom side of the trophy
bears the engraved year and name of each FIFA World Cup winner since
[1974](/wiki/1974_FIFA_World_Cup "1974 FIFA World Cup").[45] The description
of the trophy by Gazzaniga was: "The lines spring out from the base, rising in
spirals, stretching out to receive the world. From the remarkable dynamic
tensions of the compact body of the sculpture rise the figures of two athletes
at the stirring moment of victory."[46]

This new trophy is not awarded to the winning nation permanently. World Cup
winners retain the trophy only until the post-match celebration is finished.
They are awarded a gold-plated replica rather than the solid gold original
immediately afterwards.[47]

Currently, all members (players, coaches, and managers) of the top three teams
receive medals with an insignia of the [World Cup
Trophy](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy#FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy "FIFA World Cup
Trophy"); winners' (gold), runners-up' (silver), and third-place (bronze). In
the [2002 edition](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup"), fourth-
place medals were awarded to hosts [South
Korea](/wiki/South_Korea_national_football_team "South Korea national football
team"). Before the 1978 tournament, medals were only awarded to the eleven
players on the pitch at the end of the final and the third-place match. In
November 2007, FIFA announced that all members of World Cup-winning squads
between 1930 and 1974 were to be retroactively awarded winners'
medals.[48][49][50]

## Format

### Qualification

Main article: [FIFA World Cup
qualification](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "FIFA World Cup
qualification")

Since the second World Cup in [1934](/wiki/1934_FIFA_World_Cup "1934 FIFA
World Cup"), qualifying tournaments have been held to thin the field for the
final tournament.[51] They are held within the six FIFA continental zones
([Africa](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African
Football"), [Asia](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation "Asian Football
Confederation"), [North and Central America and Caribbean](/wiki/CONCACAF
"CONCACAF"), [South America](/wiki/CONMEBOL "CONMEBOL"),
[Oceania](/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation "Oceania Football
Confederation"), and [Europe](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA")), overseen by their
respective confederations. For each tournament, FIFA decides the number of
places awarded to each of the continental zones beforehand, generally based on
the relative strength of the confederations' teams.

The qualification process can start as early as almost three years before the
final tournament and last over a two-year period. The formats of the
qualification tournaments differ between confederations. Usually, one or two
places are awarded to winners of intercontinental [play-offs](/wiki/Play-off
"Play-off"). For example, the winner of the Oceanian zone and the fifth-placed
team from the Asian zone entered a play-off for a spot in the [2010 World
Cup](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World Cup").[52] From the [1938
World Cup](/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup "1938 FIFA World Cup") onwards, host
nations receive automatic qualification to the final tournament. This right
was also granted to the defending champions between 1938 and 2002, but was
withdrawn from the [2006 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA
World Cup") onward, requiring the champions to qualify.
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team"),
winners in [2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup"), were the
first defending champions to play qualifying matches.[53]

### Final tournament

For the various formats used in previous tournaments, see [History of the FIFA
World Cup § Format of each final
tournament](/wiki/History_of_the_FIFA_World_Cup#Format_of_each_final_tournament
"History of the FIFA World Cup").

The current final tournament has been used since 1998 and features 32 national
teams competing over the course of a month in the host nation(s). There are
two stages: the group stage followed by the knockout stage.[54]

In the group stage, teams compete within eight groups of four teams each.
Eight teams are seeded, including the hosts, with the other seeded teams
selected using a formula based on the [FIFA World
Rankings](/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings "FIFA World Rankings") and/or performances
in recent World Cups, and drawn to separate groups.[55] The other teams are
assigned to different "pots", usually based on geographical criteria, and
teams in each pot are drawn at random to the eight groups. Since
[1998](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup"), constraints have been
applied to the draw to ensure that no group contains more than two European
teams or more than one team from any other confederation.[56]

Each group plays a [round-robin tournament](/wiki/Round-robin_tournament
"Round-robin tournament"), in which each team is scheduled for three matches
against other teams in the same group. This means that a total of six matches
are played within a group. The last round of matches of each group is
scheduled at the same time to preserve fairness among all four teams.[57] The
top two teams from each group advance to the knockout stage. Points are used
to rank the teams within a group. Since [1994](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994
FIFA World Cup"), [three points have been awarded for a
win](/wiki/Three_points_for_a_win "Three points for a win"), one for a draw
and none for a loss (before, winners received two points).

If one considers all possible outcomes (win, draw, loss) for all six matches
in a group, there are 729 (= 36) outcome combinations possible. However, 207
of these combinations lead to ties between the second and third places. In
such case, the ranking among these teams is determined as follows:[58]

  1. Greatest combined goal difference in all group matches
  2. Greatest combined number of goals scored in all group matches
  3. If more than one team remain level after applying the above criteria, their ranking will be determined as follows: 
    1. Greatest number of points in head-to-head matches among those teams
    2. Greatest goal difference in head-to-head matches among those teams
    3. Greatest number of goals scored in head-to-head matches among those teams
    4. Fair play points, defined by the number of yellow and red cards received in the group stage: 
      1. Yellow card: minus 1 point
      2. Indirect red card (as a result of a second yellow card): minus 3 points
      3. Direct red card: minus 4 points
      4. Yellow card and direct red card: minus 5 points
  4. If any of the teams above remain level after applying the above criteria, their ranking will be determined by the drawing of lots

The knockout stage is a [single-elimination tournament](/wiki/Single-
elimination_tournament "Single-elimination tournament") in which teams play
each other in one-off matches, with [extra time](/wiki/Extra_time "Extra
time") and [penalty shootouts](/wiki/Penalty_shootout_\(association_football\)
"Penalty shootout \(association football\)") used to decide the winner if
necessary. It begins with the round of 16 (or the second round) in which the
winner of each group plays against the runner-up of another group. This is
followed by the quarter-finals, the semi-finals, the [third-place
match](/wiki/Third_place_playoff "Third place playoff") (contested by the
losing semi-finalists), and the final.[54]

On 10 January 2017, FIFA approved a new format, the 48-team World Cup (to
accommodate more teams), which consists of 16 groups of three teams each, with
two teams qualifying from each group, to form a round of 32 knockout stage, to
be implemented by 2026.[59]

## Hosts

Main article: [FIFA World Cup hosts](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_hosts "FIFA World
Cup hosts")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/World_cup_hosts.png/500px-
World_cup_hosts.png)](/wiki/File:World_cup_hosts.png)

[](/wiki/File:World_cup_hosts.png "Enlarge")

Map of FIFA World Cup final hosts, 1930–2022. Green: once; dark green: twice;
light green: planned

### Selection process

Early World Cups were given to countries at meetings of FIFA's congress. The
locations were controversial because South America and Europe were by far the
two centres of strength in football and travel between them required three
weeks by boat. The decision to hold the [first World
Cup](/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup "1930 FIFA World Cup") in Uruguay, for example,
led to only four European nations competing.[60] The next two World Cups were
both held in Europe. The decision to hold the second of these in France was
disputed, as the South American countries understood that the location would
alternate between the two continents. Both Argentina and Uruguay thus
boycotted the [1938 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup "1938 FIFA World
Cup").[61]

Since the [1958 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1958_FIFA_World_Cup "1958 FIFA World
Cup"), to avoid future boycotts or controversy, FIFA began a pattern of
alternating the hosts between the Americas and Europe, which continued until
the [1998 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup").
The [2002 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup"),
hosted jointly by South Korea and Japan, was the first one held in Asia, and
the first tournament with multiple hosts.[62] South Africa became the first
African nation to host the World Cup in [2010](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010
FIFA World Cup"). The [2014 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014
FIFA World Cup") was hosted by Brazil, the first held in South America since
[Argentina 1978](/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup "1978 FIFA World Cup"),[63] and was
the first occasion where consecutive World Cups were held outside Europe.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Russia_2018_World_Cup.jpeg/220px-
Russia_2018_World_Cup.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Russia_2018_World_Cup.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Russia_2018_World_Cup.jpeg "Enlarge")

Russian delegates celebrate being chosen as the host of the [2018 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup")

The host country is now chosen in a vote by FIFA's Council. This is done under
an [exhaustive ballot](/wiki/Exhaustive_ballot "Exhaustive ballot") system.
The national football association of a country desiring to host the event
receives a "Hosting Agreement" from FIFA, which explains the steps and
requirements that are expected from a strong bid. The bidding association also
receives a form, the submission of which represents the official confirmation
of the candidacy. After this, a FIFA designated group of inspectors visit the
country to identify that the country meets the requirements needed to host the
event and a report on the country is produced. The decision on who will host
the World Cup is usually made six or seven years in advance of the tournament.
However, there have been occasions where the hosts of multiple future
tournaments were announced at the same time, as was the case for the [2018 and
2022 World Cups](/wiki/2018_and_2022_FIFA_World_Cup_bids "2018 and 2022 FIFA
World Cup bids"), which were awarded to [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia") and
[Qatar](/wiki/Qatar "Qatar"), with Qatar becoming the first Middle Eastern
country to host the tournament.[64][65]

For the 2010 and 2014 World Cups, the final tournament is rotated between
confederations, allowing only countries from the chosen confederation (Africa
in 2010, South America in 2014) to bid to host the tournament. The rotation
policy was introduced after the
[controversy](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_hosts#2006_FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup
hosts") surrounding Germany's victory over South Africa in the vote to host
the [2006 tournament](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup").
However, the policy of continental rotation will not continue beyond 2014, so
any country, except those belonging to confederations that hosted the two
preceding tournaments, can apply as hosts for World Cups starting from
[2018](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup").[66] This is partly to
avoid a similar scenario to the bidding process for the 2014 tournament, where
Brazil was the only official bidder.[67]

The [2026 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2026_FIFA_World_Cup "2026 FIFA World Cup") was
chosen to be held in the United States, Canada and Mexico, marking the first
time a World Cup has been shared by three host nations.[68] The 2026
tournament will be the biggest World Cup ever held, with 48 teams playing 80
matches. Sixty matches will take place in the US, including all matches from
the quarter-finals onward, while Canada and Mexico will host 10 games
each.[68]

### Performances

See also: [Results of host nations in the FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/National_team_appearances_in_the_FIFA_World_Cup#Results_of_host_nations
"National team appearances in the FIFA World Cup")

Six of the eight champions have won one of their titles while playing in their
own homeland, the exceptions being
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team"),
who finished as runners-up after losing the [deciding
match](/wiki/Uruguay_v_Brazil_\(1950_FIFA_World_Cup\) "Uruguay v Brazil \(1950
FIFA World Cup\)") on home soil in 1950 and lost their semi-final against
Germany in 2014, and [Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain
national football team"), which reached the second round on home soil in 1982.
[England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national football
team") (1966) won its only title while playing as a host nation.
[Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football
team") (1930), [Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national
football team") (1934), [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team
"Argentina national football team") (1978) and
[France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national football team")
(1998) won their first titles as host nations but have gone on to win again,
while [Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national
football team") (1974) won their second title on home soil.[69]

Other nations have also been successful when hosting the tournament.
[Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland_national_football_team "Switzerland national
football team") (quarter-finals 1954),
[Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_national_football_team "Sweden national football team")
(runners-up in 1958), [Chile](/wiki/Chile_national_football_team "Chile
national football team") (third place in 1962), [South
Korea](/wiki/South_Korea_national_football_team "South Korea national football
team") (fourth place in 2002), and
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team "Mexico national football team")
(quarter-finals in 1970 and 1986) all have their best results when serving as
hosts. So far, [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa_national_football_team "South
Africa national football team") (2010) has been the only host nation to fail
to advance beyond the first round.[70]

final in half of the 20 World Cups as of 2014. Another match or matches drew

## Broadcasting and promotion

See also: [List of FIFA World Cup
broadcasters](/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_broadcasters "List of FIFA World
Cup broadcasters")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Coca_cola_world_cup_2002.jpg/170px-
Coca_cola_world_cup_2002.jpg)](/wiki/File:Coca_cola_world_cup_2002.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Coca_cola_world_cup_2002.jpg "Enlarge")

A [Coca-Cola](/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-Cola") bottle promoting the 2002 World Cup
in South Korea and Japan

The World Cup was first televised in 1954 and is now the most widely viewed
and followed sporting event in the world. The cumulative viewership of all
matches of the 2006 World Cup is estimated to be 26.29 billion.[1] 715.1
million individuals watched the final match of this tournament (a ninth of the
entire population of the planet). The 2006 World Cup draw, which decided the
distribution of teams into groups, was watched by 300 million viewers.[73] The
World Cup attracts many sponsors such as [Coca-Cola](/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-
Cola"), [McDonald's](/wiki/McDonald%27s "McDonald's") and
[Adidas](/wiki/Adidas "Adidas"). For these companies and many more, being a
sponsor strongly impacts their global brands. Host countries typically
experience a multimillion-dollar revenue increase from the month-long event.
The governing body of the sport, [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA"), generated $4.8
billion in revenue from the 2014 tournament.[74]

Each FIFA World Cup since 1966 has its own [mascot](/wiki/Mascot "Mascot") or
logo. _World Cup Willie_ , the mascot for the 1966 competition, was the first
[World Cup mascot](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_mascots "FIFA World Cup mascots").[75]
World Cups feature [official match
balls](/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_official_match_balls "List of FIFA World
Cup official match balls") specially designed for each tournament.[76] Each
World Cup also has an official song, which have been performed by artists
ranging from [Shakira](/wiki/Shakira "Shakira") to [Will
Smith](/wiki/Will_Smith "Will Smith").[77][78] Other songs, such as “[Nessun
dorma](/wiki/Nessun_dorma "Nessun dorma")”, performed by [The Three
Tenors](/wiki/The_Three_Tenors "The Three Tenors") at four World Cup concerts,
have also become identified with the tournament.[79]

The World Cup even has a statistically significant effect on birth rates, the
male/female sex ratio of newborns, and heart attacks in nations whose national
teams are competing.[80][81][82]

Notes

  1. **Jump up ^** There was no [third place match in 1930](/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup#Third_and_fourth_place "1930 FIFA World Cup"); the United States and Yugoslavia lost in the semi-finals. FIFA now recognises the United States as the third-placed team and Yugoslavia as the fourth-placed team, using the overall records of the teams in the tournament.[83]
  2. ^ Jump up to: _**a**_ _**b**_ There was no official World Cup final match in 1950.[84] The tournament winner was decided by a final round-robin group contested by four teams (Uruguay, Brazil, Sweden, and Spain). Coincidentally, one of the last two matches of the tournament pitted the two top ranked teams against each other, with [Uruguay's 2–1 victory over Brazil](/wiki/Uruguay_v_Brazil_\(1950_FIFA_World_Cup\) "Uruguay v Brazil \(1950 FIFA World Cup\)") thus often being considered as the de facto final of the 1950 World Cup.[85] Likewise, the game between the lowest ranked teams, played at the same time as Uruguay vs Brazil, can be considered equal to a 3rd place match, with Sweden's 3–1 victory over Spain ensuring that they finished third.

In all, 79 nations have [played in at least one World
Cup](/wiki/National_team_appearances_in_the_FIFA_World_Cup "National team
appearances in the FIFA World Cup").[86] Of these, eight national teams have
won the World Cup, and they have added [stars to their
badges](/wiki/Star_\(football_badge\) "Star \(football badge\)"), with each
star representing a World Cup victory. (Uruguay, however, choose to display
four stars on their badge, representing their two gold medals at the 1924 and
1928 Summer Olympics and their two World Cup titles in 1930 and 1950).

With five titles, Brazil are the most successful World Cup team and also the
only nation to have [played in every World
Cup](/wiki/National_team_appearances_in_the_FIFA_World_Cup#Ranking_of_teams_by_number_of_appearances
"National team appearances in the FIFA World Cup") (21) to date.[87] Brazil
were also the first team to win the World Cup for the third (1970), fourth
(1994) and fifth (2002) time. Italy (1934 and 1938) and Brazil (1958 and 1962)
are the only nations to have won consecutive titles. West Germany (1982–1990)
and Brazil (1994–2002) are the only nations to appear in three consecutive
World Cup finals. Germany has made the most top-four finishes (13), medals
(12), as well as the most finals (8).

### Best performances by continental zones

See also: [FIFA World Cup results by
confederation](/wiki/National_team_appearances_in_the_FIFA_World_Cup#Results_by_confederation
"National team appearances in the FIFA World Cup")

To date, the final of the World Cup has only been contested by teams from the
[UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") (Europe) and [CONMEBOL](/wiki/CONMEBOL "CONMEBOL")
(South America) confederations. European nations have won twelve titles, while
South American have won nine. Only two teams from outside these two continents
have ever reached the semi-finals of the competition: [United
States](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team "United States men's
national soccer team") ([North, Central America and Caribbean](/wiki/CONCACAF
"CONCACAF")) in 1930 and [South
Korea](/wiki/South_Korea_national_football_team "South Korea national football
team") ([Asia](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation "Asian Football
Confederation")) in 2002. The best result of an
[African](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African
Football") team is reaching the quarter-finals:
[Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroon_national_football_team "Cameroon national football
team") in 1990, [Senegal](/wiki/Senegal_national_football_team "Senegal
national football team") in 2002 and
[Ghana](/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team "Ghana national football team") in
2010. Only one [Oceanian](/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation "Oceania
Football Confederation") qualifier,
[Australia](/wiki/Australia_national_soccer_team "Australia national soccer
team") in 2006, has advanced to the second round.[88]

[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team"),
[Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national
football team"), [Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national
football team") and [Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany
national football team") are the only teams to win a World Cup outside their
continental confederation; Brazil came out victorious in [Europe](/wiki/UEFA
"UEFA") ([1958](/wiki/1958_FIFA_World_Cup "1958 FIFA World Cup")), [North
America](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF") ([1970](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup "1970
FIFA World Cup") and [1994](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup"))
and [Asia](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation "Asian Football Confederation")
([2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup")). Argentina won a
World Cup in North America in [1986](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA
World Cup"), while Spain won in
[Africa](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African
Football") in [2010](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World Cup"). In
[2014](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup"), Germany became the
first European team to win in the Americas. Only on five occasions have
consecutive World Cups been won by teams from the same continent, and
currently it is the first time with four champions in a row from the same
continental confederation. Italy and Brazil successfully defended their titles
in 1938 and 1962 respectively, while Italy's triumph in 2006 has been followed
by wins for Spain in 2010, Germany in 2014 and France in 2018. Currently, it
is also the first time that one of the currently winning continents (Europe)
is ahead of the other (South America) by more than one championship.

## Awards

Main article: [FIFA World Cup awards](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards "FIFA World
Cup awards")

At the end of each World Cup, awards are presented to the players and teams
for accomplishments other than their final team positions in the tournament.
There are currently six awards:[89]

  * The _[Golden Ball](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#Golden_Ball "FIFA World Cup awards")_ for the best player, determined by a vote of media members (first awarded in 1982); the _Silver Ball_ and the _Bronze Ball_ are awarded to the players finishing second and third in the voting respectively;[90]
  * The _[Golden Boot](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#Golden_Boot "FIFA World Cup awards")_ (sometimes called the _Golden Shoe_) for the top goalscorer (first awarded in 1982, but retrospectively applied to all tournaments from 1930); most recently, the _Silver Boot_ and the _Bronze Boot_ have been awarded to the second and third top goalscorers respectively;[91]
  * The _[Golden Glove Award](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#Golden_Glove "FIFA World Cup awards")_ (formerly the _Yashin Award_) for the best [goalkeeper](/wiki/Goalkeeper_\(association_football\) "Goalkeeper \(association football\)"), decided by the FIFA Technical Study Group (first awarded in 1994);[92]
  * The _[Best Young Player Award](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#Best_Young_Player_Award "FIFA World Cup awards")_ for the best player aged 21 or younger at the start of the calendar year, decided by the FIFA Technical Study Group (first awarded in 2006);[93]
  * The _[FIFA Fair Play Trophy](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#FIFA_Fair_Play_Trophy "FIFA World Cup awards")_ for the team with the best record of [fair play](/wiki/Sportsmanship "Sportsmanship"), according to the points system and criteria established by the FIFA Fair Play Committee (first awarded in 1978);[93]
  * The _[Most Entertaining Team](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#Most_Entertaining_Team "FIFA World Cup awards")_ for the team that has entertained the public the most during the World Cup, determined by a poll of the general public (first awarded in 1994);[93]

An _[All-Star Team](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#All-Star_Team "FIFA World Cup
awards")_ consisting of the best players of the tournament has also been
announced for each tournament since 1998.

## Records and statistics

Main article: [List of FIFA World Cup
records](/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_records "List of FIFA World Cup
records")

See also: [List of FIFA World Cup
winners](/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_winners "List of FIFA World Cup
winners")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Lothar_Matth%C3%A4us.jpg/170px-
Lothar_Matth%C3%A4us.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lothar_Matth%C3%A4us.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lothar_Matth%C3%A4us.jpg "Enlarge")

[Lothar Matthäus](/wiki/Lothar_Matth%C3%A4us "Lothar Matthäus") played a
record 25 World Cup matches across a joint record five tournaments.

Three players share the record for [playing in the most World
Cups](/wiki/List_of_players_who_have_appeared_in_multiple_FIFA_World_Cups
"List of players who have appeared in multiple FIFA World Cups");
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team "Mexico national football
team")'s [Antonio Carbajal](/wiki/Antonio_Carbajal "Antonio Carbajal")
(1950–1966) and [Rafael Márquez](/wiki/Rafael_M%C3%A1rquez "Rafael Márquez")
(2002-2018); and [Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany
national football team")'s [Lothar Matthäus](/wiki/Lothar_Matth%C3%A4us
"Lothar Matthäus") (1982–1998) all played in five tournaments.[94] Matthäus
has played the most World Cup matches overall, with 25 appearances.[95]
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football
team")'s [Djalma Santos](/wiki/Djalma_Santos "Djalma Santos") (1954–1962),
[West Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football
team")'s [Franz Beckenbauer](/wiki/Franz_Beckenbauer "Franz Beckenbauer")
(1966–1974) and [Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany
national football team")'s [Philipp Lahm](/wiki/Philipp_Lahm "Philipp Lahm")
(2006–2014) are the only players to be named to three Finals [All-Star
Teams](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#All-Star_Team "FIFA World Cup awards").[96]

[Miroslav Klose](/wiki/Miroslav_Klose "Miroslav Klose") of Germany (2002–2014)
is the all-time top scorer at the finals, with 16 goals. He broke
[Ronaldo](/wiki/Ronaldo_\(Brazilian_footballer\) "Ronaldo \(Brazilian
footballer\)") of Brazil's record of 15 goals (1998–2006) during the [2014
semi-final match against
Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_v_Germany_\(2014_FIFA_World_Cup\) "Brazil v Germany
\(2014 FIFA World Cup\)"). West Germany's [Gerd Müller](/wiki/Gerd_M%C3%BCller
"Gerd Müller") (1970–1974) is third, with 14 goals.[97] The fourth placed
goalscorer, [France](/wiki/France_national_football_team "France national
football team")'s [Just Fontaine](/wiki/Just_Fontaine "Just Fontaine"), holds
the record for the most goals scored in a single World Cup; all his 13 goals
were scored in the 1958 tournament.[98]

In November 2007, FIFA announced that all members of World Cup-winning squads
between 1930 and 1974 were to be retroactively awarded winners' medals.[48]
This made Brazil's [Pelé](/wiki/Pel%C3%A9 "Pelé") the only player to have won
three World Cup winners' medals (1958, 1962, and 1970, although he did not
play in the 1962 final due to injury),[99] with [20 other players who have won
two winners'
medals](/wiki/List_of_players_who_have_won_multiple_FIFA_World_Cups "List of
players who have won multiple FIFA World Cups"). Seven players have collected
all three types of World Cup medals (winners', runner- ups', and third-place);
five players were from [West Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team
"Germany national football team")'s squad of 1966–1974 including [Franz
Beckenbauer](/wiki/Franz_Beckenbauer "Franz Beckenbauer"), [Jürgen
Grabowski](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Grabowski "Jürgen Grabowski"), [Horst-Dieter
Höttges](/wiki/Horst-Dieter_H%C3%B6ttges "Horst-Dieter Höttges"), [Sepp
Maier](/wiki/Sepp_Maier "Sepp Maier") and [Wolfgang
Overath](/wiki/Wolfgang_Overath "Wolfgang Overath") (1966–1974), Italy's
[Franco Baresi](/wiki/Franco_Baresi "Franco Baresi") (1982, 1990, 1994) and
the most recent has been [Miroslav Klose](/wiki/Miroslav_Klose "Miroslav
Klose") of Germany (2002–2014) with four consecutive medals.[100]

Brazil's [Mário Zagallo](/wiki/M%C3%A1rio_Zagallo "Mário Zagallo"), West
Germany's [Franz Beckenbauer](/wiki/Franz_Beckenbauer "Franz Beckenbauer") and
France's [Didier Deschamps](/wiki/Didier_Deschamps "Didier Deschamps") are the
only people to date to win the World Cup as both player and head coach.
Zagallo won in 1958 and 1962 as a player and in 1970 as head coach.[101]
Beckenbauer won in 1974 as captain and in 1990 as head coach,[102] and
Deschamps repeated the feat in 2018, after having won in 1998 as captain.[103]
[Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football team")'s
[Vittorio Pozzo](/wiki/Vittorio_Pozzo "Vittorio Pozzo") is the only head coach
to ever win two World Cups (1934 and 1938).[104] All World Cup-winning head
coaches were natives of the country they coached to victory.[105]

Among the national teams, Germany and Brazil have played the most World Cup
matches (109), Germany appeared in the most finals (8), semi-finals (13),
quarter-finals (16), while Brazil has appeared in the most World Cups (21),
has the most wins (73) and has scored the most goals (229).[106][107] The two
teams have played each other twice in the World Cup, in the [2002
final](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "2002 FIFA World Cup Final") and in the
[2014 semi-final](/wiki/Brazil_v_Germany_\(2014_FIFA_World_Cup\) "Brazil v
Germany \(2014 FIFA World Cup\)").[108]
